q: Which standard is related to Metadata exchange?
expl: CWM/XMI/ISO 11179 are metadata standards.

options: Determine the downstream effects of changing a data element
expl: Lineage allows you to see what breaks if you change a column.

options: A data model of the metadata repository itself (Data about metadata)
A very large enterprise data model
expl: The schema that defines how metadata is stored.
Context = Trust. Users can find and understand data.

q: Unstructured data accounts for roughly what % of enterprise data?
expl: The '80/20 rule' applies: ~80% of data is unstructured.

options: A flat list of unorganized tags
expl: Hierarchy/Tree structure used for classification.

options: The process of identifying and collecting electronic data for legal evidence
Searching the internet for open source data
Discovering new data patterns using AI
expl: Legal search for electronic records.
Technology to convert images of text into machine-encoded text.

q: Records Management is primarily concerned with:
expl: Managing the legal lifecycle and retention schedules of records.
Social classification (e.g., hashtags).

q: Metadata embedded in a file (like EXIF in a photo) is:
expl: Stored inside the file header itself.

q: Which lifecycle phase involves the legally mandated destruction of records?
expl: Secure destruction according to retention schedules.

options: Understanding how an automated decision (AI) was made about a person
Knowing the cost of data storage
Knowing the location of the server
expl: Transparency in Algorithmic decision making.

q: Bias in AI models often stems from:
expl: Bias In = Bias Out. Models learn historical prejudices.

options: Aggregated data can hide or reverse trends present in subgroups
More data always leads to better decisions
expl: Statistical paradox where aggregation hides the truth.

q: Data Ethics is distinct from Data Privacy because:
options: Privacy is legal/compliance; Ethics is about moral obligation ('Should we?')
They are exactly the same concept
Privacy is for Europe; Ethics is for North America
Ethics is technical; Privacy is business
Ethics is optional; Privacy is mandatory
expl: Compliance asks 'Can we?'; Ethics asks 'Should we?'.

options: Informed, voluntary, and explicit agreement by the data subject
Buying data from a third party
Assuming permission based on public availability
expl: Informed consent is a cornerstone of ethical data collection.
Stripping identifiers to protect privacy.

q: The '3 Vs' of Big Data are:
expl: Size (Volume), Speed (Velocity), Shape (Variety).

options: Structure is defined strictly before loading (RDBMS)
Structure is applied only when the data is queried/analyzed
Data has no structure at all
The schema is deleted after reading
expl: Data Lake characteristic. Load raw, define structure later.

q: Supervised Learning in Machine Learning uses:
options: Unlabeled data (finding patterns on its own)
expl: Supervised = Teaching with examples (Labels). Unsupervised = Finding patterns.

options: The process of securing data centers
Cleaning, transforming, and mapping raw data for analysis
expl: Data Munging/Preparation for analytics.

options: Unnecessary visual elements that distract from the message
expl: Visual noise/clutter in dataviz.

q: MapReduce is a programming model for:
options: Distributed processing of large datasets across clusters
Reducing the size of image files
expl: Hadoop processing model (Map = split, Reduce = aggregate).

q: A Data Scientist primarily focuses on:
options: Predictive modeling, statistical analysis, and advanced analytics
expl: Advanced analytics vs Data Engineering or DBA work.

q: Sentiment Analysis is an example of:
expl: Analyzing text to determine emotion/intent.
